_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CAL/ARP RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN LEVEL III
DANDY COOLING COMPANY, LLC

1	   EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1	Accidental Release Prevention And Emergency Response Policies.
1.2	General Description Of The Stationary Source And Regulated Substances.
1.3	Summary Of The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-       Specific Prevention Steps
1.4	Summary Of The Five-Year Accident History.
1.5	Summary Of The Emergency Response Program.
1.6	Planned Changes To Improve Safety.

1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Dandy Cooling Company, LLC (Dandy) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply not to have accidental releases or emergencies.  The Company endeavors to execute this policy through the daily implementation of its Safety Programs.  Company safety programs include, but are not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM).  The PSM Program is an integrated, holistic approach to the safe operation of processes using Regulated Substances, and forms the Program Level III Prevention Program component of the RMP.  The Dandy Plant and PSM Program are specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases, and to deal safely with emergencies if and when they do happen.  It is the primary goal of Dandy to protect its employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to Company operations.  With this in mind, the priorities of protection of life, the environment, and then property have been established.  Only when these goals have been achieved may the focus shift to resumption of business operations. 

The Company also recognizes the need to be prepared for accidental releases that could occur should established prevention programs fail. The ammonia process is equipped with a state-of-the-art monitoring, control and alarm system.  The system is permitted by the Oxnard Fire/CUPA agency according to locally adopted code requirements (CFC Article 63-2001) and is supervised by a thir

d party alarm company.  If and when an ammonia leak is detected, notifications and alarms are provided to management and employees according to alarm intensity.  Automatic shutdown and ventilation systems are activated according to pre-set parameters.  In the event of a major release involving the Refrigeration Room, the supervising alarm company provides direct and immediate notification to Oxnard Fire/CUPA in addition to the other alarms and management notifications.  A secondary alarm system provides low-level alarm text messaging to refrigeration technicians when sensors detect ammonia at 20PPM, enabling early problem detection.  Our policy is to regularly test and maintain the monitoring, control and alarm systems per our Mechanical Integrity Program, which is intended to ensure proper actuation and function of the refrigeration-related systems and components on a continuous basis. 

The Company has adopted a ¿Non-responding Facility Emergency Response Policy¿.  The Plant¿s California Hazardous Material Business Plan was developed to be consistent with Emergency Action Plan requirements (i.e. notify and evacuate).  Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated through the local Certified Unified Program Agency (Oxnard Fire/CUPA); the CUPA inspects the plant and receives copies of the Business Plan updated at regular intervals.  The CUPA has been involved in the development of the plant from the initial permitting stage, and a CUPA Representative was present during portions of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  It is our policy to maintain compliance and a good working relationship with the Oxnard Fire/CUPA.

The facility is supported by its partner company, Western Precooling Systems (WPS), which has offices and staff about ¼ mile from the facility.  WPS employs ammonia technicians that are 1910.120(q) Hazardous Material Technician certified.  WPS supports RETA training and certifications for its technicians.  WPS technicians are ¿on call¿ to the facility 24/

7/365.

It is through these measures and pre-planning that Dandy endeavors to maintain effective Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response measures.    

1.2  General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Dandy Cooling is a brand-new facility located in Oxnard, CA; in a commercial/industrial area of the city. Building space occupies approximately 67,000 square feet on a 5.5 acre lot.  The refrigeration process is a state-of-the-art system engineered and installed according to the latest codes and standards as locally adopted by the City of Oxnard.  Cutting-edge safety controls are engineered directly into the plant.  Refrigeration process engineering was provided by Snowden Engineering of Salinas, CA; the refrigeration system installing contractor was Kemper Refrigeration.  The initial RMP/PSM¿Pre-startup Safety Review and IIAR Bulletin 109 Inspection (an extensive safety review of the refrigeration process and its components) will be performed by Kemper.  These companies are both known for quality work and excellent safety records.  

Two separate companies employing entirely separate workforces operate at the Plant: Dandy Cooling Company (Dandy) and Duda Farm Fresh Foods (Duda).  Dandy owns the plant and refrigeration equipment; is responsible for cooling operations, and shipping of fresh product.  Duda is responsible for processing and packaging of freshly harvested and pre-cooled celery.  Dandy receives the fresh product and pre-cools it via vacuum cooling (Hydro-Vac¿ Vacuum Tubes).  The pre-cooled celery is then delivered to the Duda side of the Plant for processing and packaging.  When the product is packaged and ready for shipping it is moved to the Dandy refrigerated storage side of the facility until shipped. The facility is open year-around with a busy season from mid-October through early July.  The remaining months see little fresh product, however the refrigeration equipment is still operative.  Annual refrigeration e

quipment maintenance is performed during low-season summer months.

The Regulated Substance in use is anhydrous ammonia (NH3) CAS #7664-41-7, which is used in a closed-loop mechanical refrigeration system.  Refrigeration equipment consists of Pressure Vessels, HydroVac¿ Vacuum Tubes, Compressors, Evaporative Condenser, Evaporators (Room Units), Water Chillers and associated valves, instrumentation and piping.  Pressure and temperature controls are installed in accordance with appropriate codes & standards, including isolation and overpressure relief valves.  Pressure relief valves are piped to a common header that terminates at an ammonia- water diffusion tank.  Pre-qualified personnel check the system daily. 

The vacuum tubes are used to pre-cool agricultural product.  Evaporators (room units) in the storage sections of the facility maintain temperature until product is sold and shipped.  The Vacuum Tubes are considered portable equipment and may move seasonally depending on market conditions & demand.  

 
1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Accidental Release Prevention Program

A Process Safety Management Plan (PSM) has been established in accordance with CCR 8, 5189.  The PSM Program is specifically intended to promote the safe operation of ammonia-handling equipment and process, and to prevent accidental releases.  Dandy strives to make the PSM Program an integral part of daily Plant operation.  Other safety programs are integrated with the PSM Program, to the extent practicable, appropriate and/or required (such as the California Injury and Illness Prevention Program/IIPP).  

WPS is the company that inspects and performs mechanical maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration equipment.  Schedules and written procedures for the operation and maintenance of ammonia-handling equipment, including the steps to be taken in the event of a release or threatened release, have been developed.  The written procedures

include necessary safety precautions for Plant operation, inspection, maintenance, and moving of portable equipment (Hydro-Vac¿ Vacuum Tubes).    As maintenance needs are determined, the need is expressed at the workload meetings conducted by the WPS Area Manager.  The specific task for the expressed need is decided by the WPS Area Manager and entered into the work order system. Tasks are then tracked to completion through the work order system.  Through this regular routine of inspect, discuss, assign and confirmation of completion, Dandy and WPS reduce equipment operational problems and potential for releases.

WPS actively encourages its ammonia technicians to seek Certification through the Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA).  Technicians only perform tasks for which they have been pre-qualified.
	
Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

It has become apparent in the industry that a mishap while draining oil from the system is one of the most common ammonia release incidents to occur.  Special self-closing valves were installed as a permissive for oil drain flow.  If a release were to develop during the oil-draining task, the mechanic simply releases the handle of the self-closing valve and flow is terminated.  These types of valves are installed at all oil drain points.

Other release prevention steps taken at the Plant:

¿	Fencing and gates to limit access by potential ¿wrong-do-ers¿.
¿	Monitoring system monitors process parameters 24/7/365.  The alarm system is continuously monitored via a third party security company.
¿	The facility is equipped with a Closed-Circuit TV (CCTV) System.    
¿	A sign-in/sign-out program is vigorously enforced.
¿	Employees are trained for hazard communication (discovery and communicating) for un-authorized personnel, suspicious activity, fires, releases or other hazardous/suspicious condition.   
¿	A strong relationship exists with the Oxnard Fire/CUPA.  Dandy has worked closely with the CUPA in the planning an

d execution of the Plant and the refrigeration system.  
¿	Staff is trained in the fire and accident prevention benefits of good housekeeping.  The general appearance of the facility is maintained on a day-to-day basis.

1.4  Five-Year Accident History

The Plant is new; there have been no accidents or releases, there is no data to report.

1.5  Emergency Response Program

This plant is specifically designed and engineered to provide for life safety and effective emergency response.  Building space is fire-alarm and fire-sprinkler equipped.  The refrigeration process¿ Control, Monitoring and Alarm System includes a backup power supply (UPS) and manual backup systems (kill switches).  Authorized personnel can access critical process system controls remotely.  The system initiates notifications, alarms, equipment shutdown and pump-down of the affected area according to the location, nature and severity of the problem.   The refrigeration process is equipped with a Fire Department Emergency Control Box and a KNOX BOX has been installed.  The KNOX is kept up-to-date via regular communications with Oxnard Fire/CUPA.  The automatic systems are regularly inspected, tested and maintained at pre-determined intervals per the process Mechanical Integrity (Inspections and Maintenance) program(s).  Employees are trained in manual discovery, emergency shutdown, evacuation and notification procedures in the highly unlikely event of a failure of the engineered safety and emergency systems.  

The Plant does not require its employees to participate in conducting emergency response activities under the HAZWOPER standard; a ¿Non-responding Facility Policy¿ has been adopted for the Plant as a whole.  In the event of an ammonia emergency, the response is to follow the procedures in the Equipment SOP¿s and the California Hazardous Material Business Plan.  The overall procedure is to shutdown if it can be done safely by qualified personnel, evacuate, and notify the local response agencies

and WPS; WPS employs technicians that are 1910.120(q) Hazardous Material Technician certified.  Plant employees are to implement hazard communications, provide for the safety of visitors and report to the established Evacuation Staging Area(s) for a head count.  Emergency response is coordinated with the City of Oxnard Fire/CUPA.  The facility has verified with Oxnard Fire/CUPA its intent to be included in the Oxnard Community Emergency Plan.    

1.6  Planned changes to improve safety

The primary mechanisms to identify and plan safety improvements include (but are not limited to):
¿	Process Hazard Analysis revalidation/update;
¿	Compliance Audits;
¿	Routine inspections, tests & maintenance (Mechanical Integrity Program);
¿	IIAR Bulletin 109 Inspections (IIAR minimum safety criteria for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration process);
¿	Dandy and WPS Internal Inspection Protocols

Programs above may result in recommendations ranging from capital improvements to routine maintenance of the plant.  Work Orders are established in parallel to identified needs.  Current planned changes to improve safety include recommendations as a result of the initial Process Hazard Analysis, which was performed January 9-11, 2008.  The recommendations have been reviewed by Dandy management and a written implementation schedule has been prepared.  The majority of recommendations are scheduled for completion by September 31, 2008; completion of all recommendations is scheduled by December 31, 2008.  A summary includes:

¿	Expansion and improvement of operating procedures and safe work practices specific to the new plant/equipment which must be developed over time
¿	Additional engineering and equipment considerations
¿	Compile all relevant documentation related to the Pre-startup Safety Review
¿	Co-ordination of the Mechanical Integrity Program with WPS
¿	Expansion of the Mechanical Integrity Program according to operating experience & history

Implementation of the above measures
has commenced according to the schedule set by the Plant management team.
